choices.C: It is a private variable in a package body whose value is consistent across all current active sessions.
choices.B: It is a public variable in a package specification whose value is consistent within a user session.
choices.A: It is a private variable defined in a procedure or function within a package body whose value is consistent within a user session.
choices.D: It is a public variable in a package specification whose value is always consistent across all current active sessions.

questions.question_text: What is the correct definition of the persistent state of a packaged variable?

discussion.content:
Yes, the correct answer is B.
Explanation - Variables/Procedure/Functions declared in Package Declaration are all public that means they can be called outside Package Body as <Package_Name.Variable_Name>.
Now the second part, a package can be called from different user sessions at the same time or separate times. In that case, the values assigned to the same variable by different sessions will be different and consistent within that session.

choices.B: the exceptions that are raised implicitly by the Oracle server and can be caught by the exception handler
choices.A: the exceptions that are explicitly raised by the program and can be caught by the exception handler
choices.C: an exception that the developer determines as abnormal, are in the declarative section and raised explicitly
choices.D: an exception that is raised automatically when the PL/SQL program violates a database rule or exceeds a system-dependent limit

questions.question_text: Which type of exceptions is qualified as nonpredefined Oracle server errors?

discussion.content: B is the right answer ( non-predefined exceptions = any other standard Oracle server error wich is raised implicitly and and u can catch it in the exception handler )

it's an 'Oracle server error' and therefore it has to be a implicitly raised error, so a correct answer can only be B or D. 'no predefined' means that it is not predefined in the sys.standard package. in my opinion B and D could be correct. if there is only one answer, i would chose B.
I think the answer is C...

choices.B: Each fetch retrieves the next consecutive row and assigns values to the target variables.
choices.D: Only the first fetch retrieves the first row and assigns values to the target variables- the second produces an error.
choices.C: They produce an error because you must close and reopen the cursor before each fetch -statement.
choices.A: Each fetch retrieves the first row and assigns values to the target variables.

choices.C: It gives an error on compilation because the exception section is used in the trigger.
choices.D: It compiles successfully but gives an error on execution because it is not a row-level trigger.
choices.B: It gives an error on compilation because it is not a row-level trigger.

discussion.content:
Yes, B. 
ORA-04082: NEW or OLD references not allowed in table level triggers
04082. 00000 - "NEW or OLD references not allowed in table level triggers"

Yes, the correct answer is B.
Explanation - In line 8, we are assigning a VARCHAR2 type variable a BOOLEAN value which is not possible. In this case you will get the error - PLS-00382: expression is of wrong type
Line 7 is correct because it's a condition.
